intro: Disparago seriphioides, commonly known as the slender false foxglove, is a herbaceous perennial native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Polemoniacaceae and is characterized by its upright stems and clusters of bell-shaped, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, wooded areas and thrives in partial to full shade. Its leaves are lance-shaped and have a slightly hairy texture, while its flowers range in color from white to pale blue. Disparago seriphioides is often found in wetlands and along stream banks, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local pollinator populations.
